edu.umass.cs.surveyman.survey

Class Block

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.umass.cs.surveyman.survey.SurveyObj
      • edu.umass.cs.surveyman.survey.Block
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable

    public class Block
extends SurveyObj
implements Comparable, Serializable

    Blocks are the basic unit of state in the survey. They are used to specify control flow. Blocks may contain questions. The order of these questions within the block may be randomized. If the user does not want questions randomized within a block, they must place each question in its own, stationary (non-randomizable) block.

    The order of blocks may be randomized.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • NEXT

        public static final String NEXT
        The next pointer.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • questions

        public List<Question> questions
        The questions that reside directly in this block (not in sub-blocks).

      • branchQ

        public Question branchQ
        The branch question associated with this block. If the branch question is derived from an ALL block, this is just set to an arbitrary question within that block. It is used for debugging purposes.

      • branchParadigm

        protected Block.BranchParadigm branchParadigm
        The branch paradigm associated with this block.

      • subBlocks

        public List<Block> subBlocks
        The sub-blocks that this block contains.

      • parentBlock

        public Block parentBlock
        The parent pointer for this block. This is null if the block is top-level.

      • idToArray

        public static int[] idToArray(String strId)
        Returns a parsed, internal representation of the input identifier string.
        Parameters:
        strId - The source identifier string.
        Returns:
        array representation of the block id, where length is the depth of the block, and randomization flags removed.

      • isRandomized

        public boolean isRandomized()
        Returns whether this block may be shuffled along with other "floating" blocks and questions inside its containing block.
        Returns:
        Boolean indicating whether this block "floats".

      • isTopLevel

        public boolean isTopLevel()
        Returns whether this block is at the top of the survey (has no parents).
        Returns:
        Boolean for whether this block is top-level.

      • before

        public boolean before(Block that)
        Compares this block to the input block. Only static blocks that are not directly related to each other (neither ancestors nor descendants) can be compared. All other blocks return false (conflation of false and bottom).
        Parameters:
        that - The block to compare.
        Returns:
        Boolean indicating whether the input precedes this block.

      • isSubblockOf

        public boolean isSubblockOf(Block b)
        Compares this block with the input block and returns true if the input is a descendant of this block.
        Parameters:
        b - The block to compare.
        Returns:
        Boolean indicating whether the input is a descendant (not direct sub-block).

        public int getBlockDepth()
        Returns the depth at which this block exists. Equivalent to the number of ancestors, plus one.
        Returns:
        The number of ancestor blocks plus one.

      • getSorted

        public static List<Block> getSorted(List<Block> blockList)
        Sorts the input block list. This must be used instead of Collections.getSorted, which will throw an error, due to inappropriate behavior in compareTo.
        Parameters:
        blockList - The block list to be sorted
        Returns:
        A sorted block list.

      • blockSize

        public int blockSize()
        Counts the number of questions directly in this block and in all sub-blocks.
        Returns:
        The total number of questions in this block and all of its descendants.

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(Object o)
        DO NOT CALL COLLECTIONS.SORT IF YOU HAVE FLOATING BLOCKS -- compareTo is transitive and you may get out-of-order blocks. Call Block.getSorted instead.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface Comparable
        Parameters:
        o - The object to compare.
        Returns:
        int if you're lucky, RuntimeException if you're not.
